workflow.name: Extract meeting details with GPT-4.1-mini and evaluate accuracy in Google Sheets
workflow.description:
## Who's it for

Developers building AI-powered workflows who want to ensure their agents work reliably. If you need to validate AI outputs, test agent behavior systematically, or build maintainable automation, this template shows you how.

## What it does

This subworkflow extracts structured meeting details (title, date, time, location, links, attendees) from natural language messages using an AI agent. It demonstrates production-ready patterns:

- **Structured output validation**: JSON schema enforcement prevents malformed responses
- **Error handling**: Graceful failures with full execution traceability
- **Automated evaluation**: Test agent accuracy against expected outputs using Google Sheets
- **Dual execution modes**: Normal extraction + evaluation/testing mode

The AI resolves relative time ("tomorrow", "next Friday") using timezone context and handles incomplete data gracefully.

## How to set it up

1. Connect OpenAI API credential to the AI agent node
2. Copy the test data sheet: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U89nPsasM2WNv1D7gEYINhDwylyxYw7BOd_i8ipFC0M/edit?usp=sharing
3. Update Google Sheet IDs in `load_eval_data` and `record_eval_output` nodes
4. Test normal mode: Execute workflow "from trigger"
5. Test evaluation mode: Execute workflow "from load_eval_data"

## Requirements

- OpenAI API key
- Google Sheets OAuth credential


## Why subworkflow architecture?

**Reusability**: Wrap AI agents in subworkflows to call them from multiple parent workflows. Extract meetings from Slack, email, or webhooks‚Äîsame agent, consistent results.

**Testability**: This pattern enables isolated testing for each AI component. Set up evaluation datasets, run automated tests, and validate accuracy before deploying to production. You can't do this easily with inline agents.

**Maintainability**: Update the agent logic once, and all parent workflows benefit. Error handling and validation are built-in, so failures are traceable with execution IDs.

**This framework includes**:
- Dual-trigger pattern (normal + evaluation modes)
- Output validation that catches silent AI failures
- Error bubbling with execution metadata for debugging
- Evaluation framework with semantic/exact matching
- Proper routing that returns output to parent workflows

## Following this pattern for other agents

To adapt this for any AI task (contact extraction, invoice processing, sentiment analysis, etc.):

1. Replace `extract_meeting_details` with your AI agent (add tools, memory, etc. as needed)
2. Update `Structured Output Parser` schema to match your data structure
3. Modify `evaluate_match` prompt for your validation criteria
4. Create test cases in Google Sheets with your inputs/expected outputs
5. Adjust `normalize_eval_data` timezone/reference time if needed

The validation, error handling, and evaluation infrastructure stays the same regardless of what your agent does.

parameters.prompt:
=Compare actual_meeting to expected_meeting and score from 1 to 5.

EXACT MATCH fields (byte-for-byte):
- date (YYYY-MM-DD): "2026-01-07" ‚â† "2026-01-08"
- time (HH:mm): "15:00" ‚â† "15:01"  
- meeting_link (full URL): "https://zoom.us/j/123" ‚â† "https://zoom.us/j/124"

SEMANTIC MATCH fields (meaning matters, wording flexible):
- title: "dentist appointment" = "dentist appt"  = "dental appointment"
- location: "731 Libertad" = "Libertad 731" = "Libertad, 731"
- attendees: "team" = "the team" (null expected ‚Üí null actual preferred)
- notes: "bring documents" = "bring your documents" "bring your documents" (null expected ‚Üí null actual preferred)

NULL handling:
- If expected is null, actual should be null (exact fields) or tolerate minor differences (semantic fields)

SCORING:
5 = Perfect match (all exact fields identical, all semantic fields equivalent)
4 = Minor semantic differences (exact fields match, semantic slightly off)
3 = Some exact fields wrong OR multiple semantic mismatches
2 = Major exact field errors (date/time/link wrong)
1 = Completely failed (multiple exact fields wrong)

Output only the number: 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5

options.systemMessage:
=You are a meeting details extractor.

Extract structured information from messages about meetings, appointments, or events.

Input:
- message_text: The message to extract from
- reference_datetime_iso: Current date/time for resolving relative terms
- timezone: IANA timezone for date/time resolution

Output (STRICT JSON only):
{
  "meeting": {
    "title": "<event title/subject>",
    "date": "<YYYY-MM-DD>",
    "time": "<HH:mm in 24h format>",
    "location": "<physical location if mentioned>",
    "meeting_link": "<URL if present>",
    "attendees": "<who's invited/attending>",
    "notes": "<any additional context>"
  },
  "reasoning": "<explain how date/time was resolved from relative terms>"
}

Rules:
- Resolve relative dates ("tomorrow", "next Friday") using reference_datetime_iso and timezone
- Date format: YYYY-MM-DD (always future date)
- Time format: HH:mm (24-hour, e.g., "14:30" not "2:30 PM")
- If field is not mentioned, use null
- Extract location AND link if both present
- Keep notes brief and relevant
- Attendees: extract only actual people/groups mentioned. Ignore message recipients like "@channel", "@everyone", "@here"
- Reasoning (separate key): explain how you resolved relative terms like "tomorrow", "next Friday", "in 2 hours"
  - Example: "'tomorrow' from 2026-01-06 15:30 EST ‚Üí 2026-01-07"
  - Example: "'next Tuesday' from 2026-01-06 ‚Üí 2026-01-13"
  - Example: "'in 1 hour' from 2026-01-06 15:30 ‚Üí 16:30"
  - If no relative terms, state: "Explicit date/time provided"

Return only valid JSON. No markdown, no extra text.

parameters.content:
# AI Meeting Extractor with Evaluation Framework

Production-ready AI agent subworkflow that extracts structured meeting details from natural language messages. Demonstrates best practices for validation, error handling, and automated testing.

### How it works

1. **Input**: Receives message text and timezone via Execute Workflow Trigger
2. **AI Extraction**: Agent parses the message and extracts meeting details (title, date, time, location, links, attendees, notes)
3. **Validation**: Checks that AI returned valid structured output
4. **Output**: Returns extracted meeting object with reasoning for date/time resolution

**Evaluation mode**: When triggered from Google Sheets, runs automated tests comparing actual vs expected outputs, scoring accuracy on a 1-5 scale.

### Setup steps

1. **Connect credentials**: 
   - Add your OpenAI API key to the `extract_meeting_details` AI Agent node
   - Add Google Sheets OAuth credential for evaluation nodes

2. **Copy the test data sheet**:
   - Make a copy of this sheet: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1U89nPsasM2WNv1D7gEYINhDwylyxYw7BOd_i8ipFC0M/edit?usp=sharing
   - Replace document ID in `load_eval_data` node (line 7 in parameters)
   - Replace document ID in `record_eval_output` node

3. **Test normal extraction**:
   - Use the pinned data in `trigger` node or provide your own message
   - Execute workflow normally to test extraction

4. **Test evaluation mode**:
   - Click "Execute workflow" button
   - Select "from load_eval_data" to run evaluations against your dataset
   - Review results in the `match` column of your Google Sheet

5. **Use in parent workflows**:
   - Add Execute Workflow node in your main workflow
   - Select this workflow
   - Pass `message_text` (string) and `timezone` (string, e.g., "America/New_York")

### Customization

- **Change extracted fields**: Modify the AI agent system prompt and JSON schema in `Structured Output Parser`
- **Adjust evaluation criteria**: Edit the `evaluate_match` prompt (currently uses 1-5 scoring with semantic matching)
- **Add test cases**: Extend your Google Sheet with more examples
- **Change timezone**: Update the default timezone in `normalize_eval_data` node

### Why subworkflow architecture?

This pattern makes AI agents **reusable** across multiple parent workflows. Call it from any workflow that needs meeting extraction, and get consistent, validated results every time.

**Key benefit**: Wrapping AI agents in subworkflows allows you to set up **evaluation for each agent individually**. This makes your workflows more testable and maintainable‚Äîyou can verify each component works correctly before integrating it into larger systems.

Perfect for learning AI agent best practices or adapting to your own extraction needs.

## Load Evaluation Data

Gets test cases from Google Sheet and normalizes them to match the format from the trigger node.

**load_eval_data**: Change the spreadsheet ID here to point to your copy of the test data sheet.

**normalize_eval_data**: 
- Sets `is_evaluating` to `true` to enable evaluation mode
- Hardcodes `now` to `2026-01-06T15:30:00Z` for consistent test results
- Sets timezone to `America/Argentina/Buenos_Aires`

‚ö†Ô∏è **Important**: The `now` and `timezone` values are linked to the test data inputs and expected outputs. If you change these values, you must also update the corresponding dates in your evaluation sheet, or tests will fail.

## AI Agent - Core Extraction Logic

This is the heart of the workflow: an AI agent that extracts meeting details from natural language text.

**What it does**:
- Takes message text, reference datetime, and timezone as input
- Uses GPT-4.1-mini to parse the message
- Returns structured JSON with meeting fields (title, date, time, location, link, attendees, notes)
- Includes reasoning explaining how relative dates/times were resolved
- Enforces output format with Structured Output Parser

**Reusing this pattern for other AI agents**:
To adapt this subworkflow for a different AI task:
1. Replace `extract_meeting_details` with your AI agent (can include tools, memory, RAG, etc.)
2. Update the Structured Output Parser schema to match your output structure
3. Adjust evaluation criteria in `evaluate_match` node
4. Update test cases in your Google Sheet with your agent's inputs/outputs

The validation, error handling, and evaluation framework stay the same regardless of what your AI agent does‚Äîwhether it's using tools, accessing memory, searching documents, or anything else!

## Output Validation & Error Handling

**validate_output**: Checks that the AI agent actually returned data.

‚ö†Ô∏è **Why this is needed**: The AI Agent node with "Continue on Error Output" sometimes takes the success path even when it fails, returning empty output. This validation catches those cases before they cause issues downstream.

**handle_error**: Stops execution and bubbles the error up to the parent workflow.

The error includes:
- Execution ID and workflow metadata for traceability
- Timestamp for logging
- Clear error message

This structured error format allows parent workflows to:
- Log errors to error tracking systems
- Send notifications with execution links
- Debug failures by jumping directly to the failed execution

Without this explicit structure, you'd only get the default error message‚Äîlosing critical context like execution IDs needed for debugging and traceability.

## Evaluation Mode Router

**not_evaluating**: Routes the workflow based on execution mode.

- **False path (evaluation mode)**: Continues to evaluation nodes
- **True path (normal mode)**: Ends workflow, returns output to parent

‚ö†Ô∏è **Why manual routing instead of "Check If Evaluating" node**: 

The built-in "Check If Evaluating" node outputs non-evaluation executions to the FALSE branch (second output). In subworkflows, this prevents the output from being returned to the parent workflow properly.

By using a manual IF node with explicit `is_evaluating` flag, we control which path returns data to the parent, ensuring the workflow works correctly both standalone and when called from other workflows.

## Evaluation: Compare Actual vs Expected

**evaluate_match**: Compares AI output against ground truth from test data.

Uses GPT-5-mini to perform semantic matching:
- **Exact match**: date, time, meeting_link (byte-for-byte)
- **Semantic match**: title, location, attendees, notes (meaning-based)
- Scores from 1-5 based on accuracy

üí° **Best practice**: Use "Categorization" metric (exact match) whenever possible‚Äîit's faster, more precise, and doesn't use LLM tokens. Only use AI-powered evaluation when you need semantic/fuzzy matching like in this example.

**Customization**: 
- Adjust the evaluation prompt to match your matching criteria
- Use more powerful models (GPT-5) for complex evaluations
- Switch to exact matching if your outputs are deterministic

**record_eval_output**: Writes results back to Google Sheet.

‚ö†Ô∏è Change the spreadsheet ID here to match your test data sheet.

Outputs:
- `actual_output`: What the AI extracted
- `metadata`: Reasoning from the AI agent
- `match`: Score from 1-5

trigger.message_text:
Hi team - let's schedule our Q1 planning session for next Tuesday at 2:30 PM. We can meet in the main conference room or use this Zoom link if anyone is remote: https://zoom.us/j/123456789

Please bring your department budgets and proposals.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
